discussion.content: MBR does not support dynamic disk....
Why choosing the option as MBR?
Doesnt the new volume need to be mirrored because of redundancy? But then theres no other free disk to mirror it? What are peoples thoughts?

i think this is Windows 7 and 
Windows 7’s mirroring – which is only available in Professional, Enterprise, and Ultimate editions

I think the volume type needs to be redundant/fault-tolerant like mirrored volume.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/vds/volume-object

questions.answer: Please review explanation for detailed answer.
questions.answer_ET: Please review explanation for detailed answer.
questions.answer_description:
Please review explanation for detailed answer.
✑ Right click on disk 1, click on initialize
✑ Choose disk and option as MBR. Hit ok.
✑ Again, right click on disk 1 and choose convert to dynamic disk.
✑ Now right click on disk 1 and choose new simple volume.
✑ Specify storage as 256000 and assign a drive letter F and choose file system as NTFS and click finish.
✑ Do the same thing for rest of space of disk 1, assigning 512000MB and using Disc G
Here are the screen shots showing this process:

questions.question_text:
A technician receives an invalid certificate error when visiting a website with port 443 enabled. Other computers on the same LAN do not exhibit this symptom.
Which of the following needs to be adjusted on the workstation to fix the issue?

discussion.content: I think it's referring to the fact that certificates have validity ranges (issued date to expiration date) and if your computer's time wasn't in that range then your computer would see the certificate as being invalid even though technically it wouldn't be.

comments.content: This is correct, date and time being incorrect do not necessarily invalidate a certificate, but its a good thing to check if a certificate is not working on only one device, and is the most likely cause of this issue.

Happened to me when my computer though
It was the year 2089.

discussion.content: Date and Time is the ONLY answer that makes any sense here.

Selected Answer: A
certification have expiration date so if your date is off you will receive this error
Funny how a+ seems to be more of a vocabulary test than a tech skill test. Unable to replicate are you serious?

comments.content: This right here Cheif

discussion.content: I prefer checking discussion than viewing the answers

Selected Answer: A
The question says the technician is the ONLY person on the same LAN that receives an error when visiting a website with port 443 (https) enabled. Invalid certifications are signs that either the website is unsafe or that the certification has expired, and may not be safe.
UEFI boot mode: doesn't have to do with internet website certifications 
Logon times: has nothing to do with invalid certifications of other websites
user access control: would limit what can be accessed, but would not explain why the user is getting an invalid certificate error
Date and Time- is the only logical answer- someone prior said, their system could have the wrong date - TLS/SSL certificates are issued for a year (or more). If the date and time is not correct on your computer/device, it won’t fall into the validity period for which the certificate has been issued. As a result, the verification will fail and an error message will be shown.
absolutely correct date and time is first thing to check ,when u suspect an issue with a digital expired certificate
Anytime you see invalid certificate, date and time is your answer

for those myself included that want to know why Date and Time is the correct answer.
according to Monzilla.org-- 
 "Certificates for secure websites (the address begins with https://) are valid only for a certain period of time. If a website presents a certificate with validity dates that don't match the date on your computer's clock, Firefox can't verify that it is secure and will show you an error page.

Such issues can often be fixed by setting the correct date, time and time zone on your computer system. If this does not solve the problem, it could be caused by other issues, such as a misconfigured web server or an expired certificate."

LuCas12 - Security reason due to the Date and Time of the certificates do not match. Its very important for this to be correct and by security protocol you will not be able to access for any port number used. this is a protocol that happens throughout connection which keeps getting updated with new certificates. hope this helps.

comments.content: port 443 is HTTPS
I think that because port 443 is for HTTP, if your systems date and time do not match the web servers then it would cause an error
I get the same error on my computer yesterday. The date and time were wrong on that old computer. I changed the date to current then everything work fine

you could aswell try scratching out ones , uac does not play apart in this in my opinion uefi boot and logon times does not change a certificate while if you ever had the incorrect date and time and try to access the net it will not work hence i feel A thats how i got to my answer
Basically if a cert is set to expire tomorrow, and your date and time is set to the day after tomorrow, the computer will be tricked into thinking the cert is expired.

discussion.content: Can anyone explain why A is the right answer?

questions.question_text:
After a security audit, a technician is tasked with implementing new measures to help secure company workstations. The new policy states that all workstations must be signed off at night, a password is necessary to boot the computer, and encryption must be enabled.
Which of the following features should the technician implement to BEST meet these requirements? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: CDG is the correct answer
If one of the requirements is " password is necessary to boot the computer," why isn't "UEFI passwords" not considered one of the correct answers???

comments.content: Considering that "all workstations must be signed off at night, a password is necessary to boot the computer, and encryption must be enabled", shouldn't the three answers be "UEFI passwords", "Login time restrictions," and "BitLocker"?? Login time restrictions would ensure that no one could be signed into a workstation at night, UEFI passwords were designed to keep unauthorized people from being able to boot up a computer at all, and BitLocker encrypts data on harddrives. So how are the other three answers correct??? I really would like to see an explanation on this, please.
Agreed. CDG.

Also clearly, the question did not request password for login windows or screensave and screen lock, that means the user might only need the pw to boot the computer, and the login time restrictions will handle the users when they can use the pc and without pw to login windows

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCG
Booting to the computer doesn't mean just from UEFI password, it could also mean booting from screensaver activated turning the computer to sleep which require password. Having screensaver also answers the computer needed to be signed-off at night, and it's also a good thing because you have two kind of passwords password from sleeping the computer, and password on bios/uefi

Selected Answer: CDG
CDG, this webpage must be on crack, lol.

Selected Answer: CDG
answer is cdg

Selected Answer: CDG
CDG is the correct answer.

Proffessor Messer Obj 2.7 Note:
BIOS/UEFI passwords
• Supervisor/Administrator password: Prevent BIOS changes
• User password: Prevent booting
Login time restrictions
• Only login during working hours
• Restrict after-hours activities
Therefore, I agree with all of you saying CDG is the answer

BIOS/UEFI passwords
• Supervisor/Administrator password: Prevent BIOS changes
• User password: Prevent booting
Therefore, the correct answer should be CDG
I'm gonna go with CDG

Often there are two or more answers that could be correct and the trick is to go with how compTIA sees it. In this case, I personally believe A,B are just simply incorrect. If you google search anything worded like - "How can I limit my employees logon hours"... you will get a pretty clear answer that has to do with logon time restrictions. If you google search anything like "how to setup a boot password", you will see the clear answer deals with UEFI / BIOS. I know compTIA may have their way of thinking about some questions, but this Q/A is just a different story. I would absolutely answer CDG on the exam, but thats just me.
Are they trolling us with these answers? ABG? are you serious? Clearly CDG.

Selected Answer: CDG
all workstations must be signed off at night, a password is necessary to boot the computer, and encryption must be enabled. Therefore the answer would be "UEFI passwords", "Login time restrictions," and "BitLocker"
wouldnt A and B be the same if A meant sleep or hibernation.. sure. But it doesnt - also wouldnt we want MFA? My thoughts here are AFG

ADG or BDG
I know from experience that BitLocker also requires password on bootup as long as you encrypt the drive that has the OS on it. So using both C and G would be redundant. BitLocker would fulfill two requirements so it would be better than a UEFI password.
die Richtlinie sagt in der Nacht müssen alle logoff, mit A und B geht nicht, weil der Benutzer einfach den Computer nutzen , mit beschränkte Zeit kann aber nicht
CDG. Do people intentionally put the wrong answers on here?

comments.content: Don't think comptia can shut down a website from overseas. I call bs here. comptia is not that powerful.
Agreed. And yes, I believe they do. I've heard it's the only way these sites are allowed to continue operating. Otherwise, CompTIA would shut them down.

discussion.content: Correct answer is CDG, no discussion

UEFI password will not be consider correct answer. Because you need UEFI Password BEFORE booting up the operating system. But the question did not mention that password must be entered BEFORE booting up the system.

comments.content: That's exactly what it says. A password is required to boot. Therefore, it must be entered beforehand or it will not boot. I agree with many others here. CDG

discussion.content:
The Answer are A, C, and G

OBJ-2.7: These requirements can be met by enabling BitLocker to encrypt the hard drive, enable a UEFI password to require a password to be entered before booting an operating system, and enabling a screen lock that turns on after 2 minutes of inactivity.

comments.content: After looking back at the question, I believe it is CDG since we want to restrict users from using the computers at night

discussion.content:
It can’t be Login time restrictions, since it only says to ‘sign them off’ not to restrict use during night.

It can be UEFI, because it is only asking to fully Encrypt(password) the workstation. It didn’t specify to encrypt just the OS or such, just my opinion.

comments.content: Logon time restrictions will automatically sign out an account once its time has expired

discussion.content: I think the answers might be correct since BitLocker can be set to require password on start-up.

comments.content: These questions and options aren't written by CompTIA. They are remembered by exam takers and then given the suggested correct answers when submitting to the site. Nobody can see if the answers are correct or not after taking the exam but everybody can see whoever submitted these answers was wrong.

discussion.content: What I need to know is what does Comptia want; the correct answer or this obviously wrong one?

comments.content: That's because they all copy each other. If an answer is wrong they ALL have a wrong answer.

This is what happens when you get bots copying each others content and nobody moderating or correcting at any point. CDG is correct and whomever submitted these as the suggested correct answers to this site is wrong. 
You should use this site as a practice and jumping off point to your own research and revision. When you can identify the wrong answers as well as the right answers you will be almost ready for the exam (these exam dump questions are definitely in the real exam question pool).

discussion.content: So CDG would apply in the real world but 4 other CompTIA A+ core 2 study sites list the same answer for the exam
In my opinion, I would choose C, D and G. They make more sense than the others.

3 requirements have to meet: 
-computer signed off at night: Login time restrictions (D)
-password to boot: UEFI passwords (C)
-encryption enabled: BitLocker (G)

The new policy states that all workstations must be signed off at night, a password is necessary to boot the computer, and encryption must be enabled.
Three parts of this question, choosing the BEST options for these workstations is ABG
The reason I think it isn't UEFI passwords is because you can have more than one user working on a workstation. Each user then would need password protection in order to protect data from each other.

BIOS/UEFI Password - A system user password is one that is required before any OS can boot. 

Account Restrictions - Logon Time Restrictions: Access to the server may be restricted to particular times. The server checks whether the user has the right to continue using the network. If the user does not have the right, then an automatic logout procedure commences. 

Desktop Lock and Time out: Another way of locking the computer is to set the "screen saver" to password protect on resume. The screensaver can be set to "timeout and lock the desktop" after a set period of inactivity. 

Overall, require users to cook unattended systems (REQUIRE USERS), AND, IMPLEMENT timeouts for unattended systems.
Im going with CDG
Login time restrictions could log you out automatically, I think.

Maybe it's correct, because it says that the computers need to be signed off at night, so screen locks could work (with login time restrictions I think it won't automatically log you off, unless you do it manually). Screensaver passwords would work for the boot, although it shouldn't be called boot, because the computers are not turned off (they are signed off). And of course BitLocker for the encryption.

comments.content: Also BitLocker can provide password on boot

discussion.content: Agreed. It's too bad we can't verify these answers are what CompTIA is looking for and then learn why the answers revealed are the "best" answers.
These answers are wrong. As Sage stated previously, the answers should be CDG

questions.question_text:
A new business will be using credit cards in a physical location as well as its web presence.
Which of the following does the business need?

discussion.content:
PCI: Acronym for “Payment Card Industry.” PCI DSS: Acronym for “Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard.”

CI Compliance is an ongoing process that aids in preventing security breaches and payment card data theft in the present and in the future; PCI compliance means you are contributing to a global payment card data security solution

PCI DSS (Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard) A standard that sets common rules for systems that accept, process, transmit, or store credit/debit card payments. Often referred to as just PCI.
PCI (Payment Card Industry)
B. PCI compliance

questions.question_text:
A technician has been dispatched to resolve a malware problem on a user's workstation. The antivirus program discovered several hundred potential malware items on the workstation and removed them successfully. The technician decides to schedule daily scans on the system, enables System Restore, and creates a restore point.
Which of the following should the technician do NEXT?

choices.C: Install all of the latest Windows Updates to patch the system
choices.A: Run the scan again to ensure all malware has been removed
choices.B: Quarantine the infected workstation from the network
choices.D: Educate the user on safe browsing practices

discussion.content: Athough I don't disagree that the "best" answer should be part of the process but the CompTIA malware best practices does not list that as an option. Instead, educating the user is the only option to choose based on CompTIA's process.

comments.content:
a good mnemonic for this is 
I
Question
Dad's
Reasons
Some
Early
Evenings
This saying helped me out a lot thanks!!

The question says "Which of the following should the technician do next?" - The technician should educate the user, regardless of what the user was doing when the workstation caught malware. Remember, the sentence says a "user's workstation".

discussion.content:
The question has already gone through 6 steps of malware removal, the last step is "Educate the user" - The correct answer.

The 7 Steps/Best Practices of Malware Removal
IQDRSEE
1 - Identify and research malware symptoms
2 - Quarantine infected systems
3 - Disable System Restore
4 - Remediate infected systems (update antimalware software/scan and use removal techniques)
5 - Schedule scans and run updates
6 - Enable system restore and create restore point
7 - Educate the user

Selected Answer: D
it's definetly D
C is the probable correct answer because whoever asshole made this question is a word minipulator. Its said the technician DECIDED... means he hasn't done those steps yet!!!
Answer C is correct as the technician has decided to do those things but hasn't done them yet. The next step will be to patch the system.

The Antivirus Program Discovered Several Hundred Potential malware items on the workstation. It makes sense that this is the correct answer. I see it as a corrective measure to prevent it from passing again, with so many malware at the same time.


"Educate The User on Safe Browsing Practices", is also accepted, the useful does not know anything about computer security.
the correct answer here is "what will be correct on the exam" - I believe D will be correct on the exam, as stated.

Selected Answer: C
C. Install all of the latest Windows Updates to patch the system
The question did not mention that the technician ran the updates as part of Step 5 which also includes scheduling scans.

Selected Answer: D
This is the right answer

The correct answer should be between C and D. It gonna be good if the answer D just said "Educate the user". But they added "on safe browsing practices" to confuse the candidate. So I agree with the answer C : Install all of the latest Windows Updates to patch the system

Selected Answer: D
1. Identify and research malware symptoms.
2. Quarantine the infected systems.
3. Disable System Restore (in Windows).
4. Remediate the infected systems.
A. Update the anti-malware software.
B. Scan and use removal techniques (Safe Mode, Preinstallation
Environment).
5. Schedule scans and run updates.
6. Enable System Restore and create a restore point (in Windows).
7. Educate the end user.
l would install updates to patch the system after," schedule daily scans on the system, enables System Restore, and creates a restore point."
D. Is the correct answer.

CompTIA is very good at warping questions. This one for example is meant to confuse you. It displays that all the steps were completed by mixing them in its order, except the last step, which is D, educate the user.
The correct answer here is C. The remediation, which is step 4 on the malware`s removal was overlooked, hence the answer.

comments.content: remediation was covered in the question, read it again. the correct answer is D

ERI you are absolutely correct, however;
